title: callback in web3

body: Also, deploy is async so you need to wait until it is finished deploying before you can send transactions. So currently your transaction call will probably try to run before the contract is deployed and this will cause a problem.
Sorry, I'm not really sure what you are asking about now. Can you pose your question again and simplify it so it is very clear to see what is not working?

> Sorry, I'm not really sure what you are asking about now. Can you pose your question again and simplify it so it is very clear to see what is not working?
Hi @eggplantzzz the real issue in simple terms is..
```
const by = await contract.methods.getTransactionCount().call();
```
the return value of this call is null even after explicit insertion into the contract.
and I am not able to get it run with or without then,async/await methods.
is there any issue regarding same.
Can you provide a more complete example of your code? I can't see what transactions is etc.

It's probably because you are not "await"ing your transactions and that code is trying to run out of order. To make everything that is happening clearer, I would recommend you NOT to use BOTH async/await syntax and "then". So for example, get rid of all the "then"s you have there (and probably all the callbacks passed in the function calls) and just use await. You need to await async functions so they have time to complete before you run the rest of the code. Otherwise everything gets run out of order and values that you expect to be set have not been set.

Also spend some time formatting your code more regularly so that it is a bit more readable. I think that will help you debug it.
And just another note...basically every call you make in there needs to be "await"ed starting with `const xl = await contract.deploy({ data: bytecode });`.

That is definitely not the same thing! One of your calls is failing for some reason. You'll have to log and figure out which promise is being rejected. Once you figure out which call is failing it should be easier to focus on that part and figure out what is causing it to fail.

Also, `web3.eth.getAccounts` returns a Promise that resolves with the accounts. It is thenable, but that doesn't mean you need a then at the end. The `then` is not doing anything, remove it :)

Also, the web3 docs say that `contract.deploy(` returns a new contract instance. You might need to call transactions with that object rather than the original `contract` that you set at the start of that function.
Hi @vaisakh92 are you still having issues with web3? Let us know, thanks!

`accounts` will be set as it returns a promise that resolves with the accounts. Just `const accounts = await web3.eth.getAccounts();` is enough. The same goes for `xl.send(....`, `xl.methods.newTransaction(...`, and `contract.methods.getTransactionCount().call();`. They are ALL async methods and you will have to `await` them.

Currently it looks as though your `console.log(...` will be run before those values are set because you are not waiting until those values are set from those `async` methods.

Also, `contract.deploy(...` is async as well so you will need to `await` that.

I believe you will have to send transactions using the instance that web3 returns. In other words, use `xl` as your contract instance and call methods from it instead of `contract`. I hope that helps.

What is this call to `send` doing? Is that really a method on the contract object?
What is `xl` after you deploy it? Log it, does it look like a contract instance? Again, all those methods are `async` so you will have to await them.

> What is this call to `send` doing? Is that really a method on the contract object?
> What is `xl` after you deploy it? Log it, does it look like a contract instance? Again, all those methods are `async` so you will have to await them.

the xl object is
```
{ [Function: ContractMethod]
  call: { [Function] request: [Function] },
  send: { [Function] request: [Function] },
  estimateGas: [Function],
  encodeABI: [Function] }
```
contract instance of the contract mentioned in the code above.
but still using the send function to communicate with truffle is not working.

At this point, this actually has nothing really to do with Truffle actually. You are not really using Truffle, you are just trying to run a bunch of web3 contract object methods in a function :) You are in Web3 land. You should probably check out the web3 docs to help you do what you are trying to do. Here are the docs for web3 contract objects https://web3js.readthedocs.io/en/1.0/web3-eth-contract.html
Closing this for maintenance.
